variants.HGVS: N.D. (Need to call relevant API to standardize, preliminary: cDNA change would suggest a change from Glutamic acid (E) at position 163 to Lysine (K), but exact HGVS not given in text. Assuming a common transcript NM_007262.3, it could potentially be NM_007262.3:c.488A>G based on amino acid change, but this needs API standardization)

cDNA Change.transcript: N.D. (Assuming NM_007262.3 for example purposes, but needs API standardization)

variants.Description in input context: A novel homozygous missense mutation resulting in the E163K amino acid substitution

Material used.Material Name: N2A (mouse neuroblastoma) and CHO (Chinese Hamster Ovary)
Material used.Description: Native N2A and CHO cells or stable clonal lines expressing WT or E163K human DJ-1 were used. Cells were grown to confluency, rinsed and scraped in PBS, and harvested by centrifugation.

Experiment Method.Readout type: Qualitative (distribution of proteins in different fractions)

Readout description.Conclusion: No differences in protein solubility between WT and E163K variants
Readout description.Result Description: The WT and the E163K mutant form of human DJ-1 both were extracted most abundantly in the soluble Triton X - 100 fractions (TX1 and TX2) and to a lesser extent in the RIPA fractions. Neither E163K mutant nor WT DJ-1 were detected in the SDS fractions, and there were no differences between the distribution of WT and E163K DJ-1 across any of the biochemical fractions.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, similar distribution of WT protein across fractions could be considered normal)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, significant difference in distribution of mutant protein compared to WT across fractions could be considered abnormal)

Material used.Material Name: N2A (mouse neuroblastoma) and CHO (Chinese Hamster Ovary)
Material used.Description: N2A or CHO cells and stable cell lines thereof were cultured in 10 cm dishes and grown to confluency. Cells were rinsed and scraped in phosphate buffered saline, pH 7.4. After recovery by centrifugation, cells were lysed in PBS/0.1% Triton and the cell debris was sedimented.

Experiment Method.Readout type: Qualitative (elution fractions corresponding to molecular mass)

Readout description.Conclusion: Both WT and E163K mutant DJ-1 form dimers
Readout description.Result Description: Both the WT DJ-1 and the E163K mutant DJ-1 exclusively eluted in fractions 24 through 26 in N2A cells (corresponding to a molecular mass of âˆ¼42 kDa, the proposed molecular mass for the DJ-1 dimer). In CHO cells, both the WT and the E163K mutant DJ-1 protein eluted in fractions 24 and 25.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, elution in fractions corresponding to dimer mass for WT could be considered normal)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, elution in fractions not corresponding to dimer mass for mutant could be considered abnormal)

Material used.Material Name: N2A (mouse neuroblastoma) and CHO (Chinese Hamster Ovary)
Material used.Description: N2A or CHO cells stably expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured in 6 - well dishes. Cells were methionine - deprived and then pulsed with [35S]-methionine and chased with normal DMEM/FBS.

Readout description.Conclusion: The E163K mutant shows comparable stability to WT
Readout description.Result Description: Both the E163K mutant and WT DJ-1 proteins showed similar turnover in N2A cells and also in CHO cells.

Biological replicates.Description: Chase experiments were conducted in quadruplicates

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, similar turnover rate to WT could be considered normal)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, significantly different turnover rate compared to WT could be considered abnormal)

Material used.Description: Native N2A, or N2A cells stably expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured in 10 cm plates. Cells were rinsed and scraped in phosphate - buffered saline, pH 7.4 and processed for subcellular fractionation.

Experiment Method.Readout type: Qualitative (protein distribution in cytosolic and mitochondrial fractions)

Readout description.Conclusion: The E163K mutant does not show altered subcellular localization
Readout description.Result Description: Endogenous DJ-1 protein in N2A cells and both human WT and E163K DJ-1 expressed in these cells demonstrated similar predominant cytoplasmic distributions.

Biological replicates.Description: Untransfected N2A cells and N2A cells stably expressing either human WT DJ-1 or human E163K DJ-1 were homogenized in triplicate

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, similar distribution to WT could be considered normal)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, significantly different distribution compared to WT could be considered abnormal)

Material used.Description: Native N2A or N2A cell lines expressing WT or E163K DJ-1 were cultured separately into 48 - well plates and treated with various stressors.

Readout description.Conclusion: The E163K mutant protein fails to rescue under conditions of oxidative stress
Readout description.Molecular Effect: partial loss - of - function (specifically for oxidative stress protection)
Readout description.Result Description: Native N2A cells or N2A cells stably expressing WT or E163K human DJ-1 were treated with various stressors. N2A cells demonstrated reduced cell viability to MG - 132 treatment at all concentrations used (10 - 30 uM). N2A cells were vulnerable to MPP dihydrochloride concentrations that exceeded 10 uM. WT DJ-1 protein was able to protect against both of these stressors at all toxic concentrations tested. Expression of E163K DJ-1 was also able to protect against MG - 132 and MPP dihydrochloride toxicity. However, N2A cells expressing E163K mutant DJ-1 showed increased vulnerability to H2O2 oxidative stress at all concentrations used, while N2A cells stably expressing human WT DJ-1 demonstrated protection against H2O2 stress.

Biological replicates.Description: Each cell type was treated in sextuplicates

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, similar viability to untreated cells could be considered normal)

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, significant decrease in viability compared to untreated cells could be considered abnormal)

Material used.Description: N2A cells were mock transfected or transiently transfected with pc3.1E163KhDJ1 - NFlag, or pc3.1WThDJ1 - NFlag constructs and then lysed.

Readout description.Conclusion: Human exogenous DJ-1 protein does not co - immunoprecipate with endogenous DJ-1 in N2A cells
Readout description.Result Description: Endogenous DJ-1 protein was not pulled down by immunoprecipitation with either WT - flag tagged or E163K - flag tagged DJ-1.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: N.D. (Based on knowledge, no heterodimer formation as in non - transfected cells could be considered normal)
